Description

Normally a part of generation stage (bskyed rim) practices, maṇḍala rituals involve the ritual creation of deities, along with their abodes and entourages, which are worshipped either as external objects (phyi'i dkyil 'khor) or else internally within one’s own body (lus dkyil).

External maṇḍala rituals first require the creation of a representation (rten) of the deity’s palace (gzhal yas khang); these can take the form of a drawing or painting on cloth (ras bris), a diagram using colored-powders (rdul tshon), heaps of grain (tshom bu), or a three-dimensional (blos bslangs pa'i) model. Such representations are called "method maṇḍalas" (thabs kyi dkyil 'khor), "symbolic maṇḍalas" (brda'i dkyil 'khor), or "image maṇḍalas" (gzungs brnyan gyi dkyil 'khor).

Explanations of these rituals vary according to different sectarian traditions and different classes of tantra. However, in general, representations of the deities of the maṇḍala, called "commitment beings" (dam tshig pa), are first generated from the seed syllables or hand implements of the various deities. Animate forms of those same deities, called "gnosis gods" (ye shes pa'i lha), are then invited to descend, dissolve, and remain within their "commitment" duplicates. Offerings, praises, confession, etc. are made to the deities, and the adept also meditates on the four immeasurables.

These rituals are usually a part of other tantric ceremonies, like empowerments, but they can also exist as independent rituals. After the ceremony is concluded, the deities are sent back to their own abodes, the commitment beings are reabsorbed into oneself, and if a colored-powder maṇḍala has been used, the powders are re-collected and the maṇḍala is ritually destroyed. Maṇḍala rituals as just described are also known as “the generation in front” (mdun bskyed).

Further rituals involve the drawing of the lines of the maṇḍalas, the application of color, and the final destruction of the maṇḍala. These are mostly found in the full maṇḍala rituals themselves, but sometimes can be found as separate texts.
